articles.headline: Your Data Is Crucial to a Robotic Age. Shouldn’t You Be Paid for It?
articles.snippet: Getting companies to pay for the information they reap from people’s online lives will improve the data and may counteract a concentration of power.
articles.abstract: Getting companies to pay for the information they reap from people’s online lives will improve the data and may counteract a concentration of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Should Facebook pay us for our puppy pictures?

articles.headline: Gary Cohn Says He Will Resign as Trump’s Top Economic Adviser
articles.snippet: Mr. Cohn had made clear his opposition to the steel and aluminum tariffs that Mr. Trump plans to impose. It’s the latest departure from a White House in chaos.
articles.abstract: Mr. Cohn had made clear his opposition to the steel and aluminum tariffs that Mr. Trump plans to impose. It’s the latest departure from a White House in chaos.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gary D. Cohn, President Trump’s top economic adviser, said on Tuesday that he would resign, becoming the latest in a series of high-profile departures from the Trump administration.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Adviser to Emirates With Ties to Trump Aides Is Cooperating With Special Counsel
articles.snippet: The special counsel has asked about the role of the adviser, George Nader, in a January 2017 meeting in the Seychelles involving a Russian investor and a Trump transition adviser.
articles.abstract: The special counsel has asked about the role of the adviser, George Nader, in a January 2017 meeting in the Seychelles involving a Russian investor and a Trump transition adviser.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An adviser to the United Arab Emirates with ties to current and former aides to President Trump is cooperating with the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, and gave testimony last week to a grand jury, according to two people familiar with the matter.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, David D. Kirkpatrick and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: The New U.S.-China Rivalry: A Technology Race
articles.snippet: The conflict over access to emerging technologies has become painfully clear with the attempt at a hostile takeover of the American chip maker Qualcomm.
articles.abstract: The conflict over access to emerging technologies has become painfully clear with the attempt at a hostile takeover of the American chip maker Qualcomm.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the United States and China look to protect their national security needs and economic interests, the fight between the two financial superpowers is increasingly focused on a single area: technology.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: On North Korea, Trump Finds Himself in Same Position as His Predecessors
articles.snippet: North Korea’s offer to put its nuclear weapons on the bargaining table opens the door to negotiations of unpredictable length and inevitable complexity.
articles.abstract: North Korea’s offer to put its nuclear weapons on the bargaining table opens the door to negotiations of unpredictable length and inevitable complexity.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the day he took office, President Trump has vowed not to repeat what he regarded as the cardinal error of his predecessors in dealing with North Korea. He would not get drawn into a lengthy negotiation in which the United States offers concessions that keep the North Korean regime alive, while the North Koreans retain the key elements of their nuclear arsenal.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Raising Hopes, North Korea Offers to Talk About Its Nuclear Arsenal
articles.snippet: South Korea says the North is open to negotiations with the United States over its nuclear program but wants military threats eliminated and its security guaranteed.
articles.abstract: South Korea says the North is open to negotiations with the United States over its nuclear program but wants military threats eliminated and its security guaranteed.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s sudden willingness to bargain with the Trump administration over scrapping its atomic arsenal surprised the world on Tuesday, setting in motion an unpredictable diplomatic dance with the United States and South Korea, but raising hopes that one of the most dangerous confrontations of the nuclear age could be defused.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and Mark Landler

articles.headline: For Two Months, I Got My News From Print Newspapers. Here’s What I Learned.
articles.snippet: Our tech columnist tried to skip digital news for a while. His old-school experiment led to three main conclusions.
articles.abstract: Our tech columnist tried to skip digital news for a while. His old-school experiment led to three main conclusions.
articles.lead_paragraph: I first got news of the school shooting in Parkland, Fla., via an alert on my watch. Even though I had turned off news notifications months ago, the biggest news still somehow finds a way to slip through.

articles.headline: North Korean Leader, Known for His Bluster, Reveals Diplomatic Skills
articles.snippet: Kim Jong-un’s meeting with South Korean envoys was a remarkable shift, just months after he raised fears of nuclear war.
articles.abstract: Kim Jong-un’s meeting with South Korean envoys was a remarkable shift, just months after he raised fears of nuclear war.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — He has never traveled abroad as North Korea’s supreme leader. Until this week, his close encounters with foreign guests had been limited to dignitaries from China, Cuba and Syria — and Dennis Rodman. He increasingly resembles his grandfather, a national deity, down to the coifed flattop, gregarious grin and rotund waist.
